div1.p: The writer discusses White's paper on yellow fever, and believes it would be useful to local doctors in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter to Wickliffe Rose, August 17, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC.
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes.” August 17, 1922.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I am returning the paper of Dr. White, received last evening, on
-the Epidemiology and Prophylaxis of Yellow Fever. Your letter of Aug. 10th,
with which it was enclosed, asks for an expression of opinion as to value
of the article and criticism thereof.

For the first, the answer is easy. It should be valuable to “the
average Mexican practitioner,” for whom it is intended, as it sets forth
many facts in the epidemiology and prophylaxis of yellow fever clearly
and simply.

For the second, except for the first paragraph, I would have no
criticism to make.

Since, however, the writer purposes to confine himself to proven
facts it is a question if it is proven

(1) That the man sick of yellow fever always ceases to be in-
fective to mosquitoes after 72 hours.

(2) That the mosquito can never convey infection to another man
until 12 days after her infecting meal.

(3) That the spirochete of Noguchi is the causative organism of
yellow fever.

For the 1st. there is evidcence, negative necessarily, but I think
it has not been generally considered proof.

For the 2nd. the same may be said. Note too that Noguchi has in-
fected a guinea pig with Leptospira icteroides by a Stegomyia mosquito
on the 8th. day after the infecting feeding. The presumption is that
this insect would have infected a man on the same date.
date.

For the 3rd., although I am inclined to accept L. icteroides as the
causarive agent in yellow fever, yet other men, whose opinions should
be of more value in this matter than mine--e. g. Welch: Rosenau: Noc:
Guiteras--do not consider this matter proven. Indeed, the last is not
only unconvinced, but well nigh convinced of the contrary, and while I
think his opinion is at least partly due to an unconscious partisanship,
yet it is as I have stated.

Would it then be fair to say that this postulate is generally ac-
cepted as proven?

I would not have said so much on this, the 3rd., paragraph, but for
the intention expressed in the 1st. one: “to state only proven facts.”
To express this paragraph in accordance with the 1st. one, as I feel
sure Dr. White intended, it might be written:

“In our experimental work we have not found the mosquito to con-
vey the disease to man unless (1) she has bitten a yellow fever pa-
tient during the first 72 hours of his illness and (2) there has been
a delay of 12 days from this feeding.”

(b) Page 1: Larvae are found in wells lined with brick or tile,
but I presume both would be considered as stone.
(c) Page 2: See remarks on the 3rd. Par.

A few typographical errors are noted in pencil on the margin with
(?) when there is any doubt.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Enclosure.
Address:
New Glasgow P. O.
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes.”

div1.head: Memorandum for Dr. Rose
div1.p:
Memorandum
for
Dr. Rose.

Connor was kind enough to send me a beautiful paper:
“Notes on Yellow Fever in Mexico,” which he intended to read
in Mexico City. Indeed, an excellent one.
